Award.AwardTitle: Optimizing Ion Mobility, Chemical Stability, and Mechanical Rigidity in Composite Electrolytes
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Energy storage is a critical aspect of sustainable and renewable energy technologies, and mobile information systems. While the chemical nature of anode and cathode determines the amount of energy that can be stored in a battery of a given size, the separator material (or electrolyte) controls its charge cycling rates, lifetime, and structural integrity. High conductance of the ion responsible for the electrochemical conversion (e.g., lithium) facilitates high power release and short recharge times. Chemical compatibility between electrolyte and electrode materials prevents the formation of blocking layers that would suppress the electrochemical process. Mechanical rigidity of the electrolyte inhibits dendrite growth that can short circuit the device and lead to catastrophic failure (e.g., spontaneous combustion). Unfortunately, these performance criteria rely on conflicting materials properties, and the challenge lies in devising a composite structure that maximizes all these attributes. In this research, a combination of simulation-based predictive design, advanced materials synthesis approaches, microstructural characterization, and performance monitoring is employed to develop new composite electrolytes with unsurpassed performance. This project contributes to the development of human resources in an innovative way by training a doctoral student in combining experimental and computational tools of investigation, and providing research experiences for undergraduate students. Connections with secondary school educators are reached through an ASM High School Teachers Camp. As well, they are pursuing a new masters mentoring program for students from minority serving institutions. It is expected to have a dual benefit - on one hand, students are gaining insight into scientific research, and on the other hand, faculty are better-positioned to proactively recruit underrepresented minorities and women into doctoral programs in science and engineering.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The objective of this research is to develop composite battery electrolytes that exhibit high Li+ conductivity, that are mechanically rigid enough to suppress lithium dendrite growth and safely separate electrodes in self-supporting device structures, and that possess an electrochemical stability range wide enough to accommodate large electrode potential differences. While high ionic conductivity and transference numbers are important for the charge-discharge rates of batteries, stiffness and electrochemical stability are essential for taking advantage of the full redox potential of Li metal, and thus increase the gravimetric capacity of energy storage for these devices. A combination of molecular simulation-based predictive design, hybrid organic-inorganic sol-gel synthesis, in situ monitoring of microstructural developments using inelastic light scattering, and dielectric impedance measurements is used to systematically explore materials chemistries and building block functionalities for the creation of nano-porous heterogeneous electrolytes. By targeting enhanced stiffness, geometrically optimized Li+ migration paths, minimal dissipative coupling between cation and donor, and tunable redox potentials, these hybrid network structures are designed to exhibit unsurpassed performance as rechargeable battery electrolytes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The availability of effective solid-state electrolytes is key to the development of high-energy and power density batteries. The three principal performance characteristics of solid-state electrolytes are: (i) selectively high Li ion conductivity, providing adequate power density for the device; (ii) high mechanical stiffness to suppress dendrite growth during charging, provide load bearing functionality, and effect volume reduction; and (iii) chemical compatibility with the electrodes to prevent unwanted degradation and electrode passivation.  In particular, the first two properties tend to vary oppositely upon varying the characteristics of a single-phase electrolyte materials.  Materials design therefore requires a composite approach and the ability to accurately predict the influence of each materials design parameter on the electrolyte performance characteristics to select the optimal combination of constituents.

The various electrolyte design principles pursued during this project were introduced sequentially so as to clearly assess each feature’s contribution to the overall performance of the material. The investigation of two series of inorganic glasses, in which structural complexity could be widely varied, served to develop an improved statistical mechanical model for the description of ion transport mechanisms in the context of structural characteristics and their elastic properties. Our analysis revealed that the particles surrounding the migrating ion are displaced isotropically outward rather than in a shear deformation mode when the ion hops between stable sites. Our formalism allows one to assess the importance of coordinating the motion of all particles affected by such a jump relative to the ability of focusing the vibrational energy onto the affected region so as to permit the hopping ion to overcome the activation barrier between sites. Typically, between 25 and 35 atoms are involved in this process. Our model provides relatively simple materials selection criteria.

Next, composites of organic polymers and inorganic particles or networks were investigated. The level of integration between the two phases was varied from mechanical blends to so-called hybrid materials, in which covalent bonds are formed between the organic and inorganic constituents. In polymer matrix composites (blends) containing active nano-particles, i.e., containing the migrating cation species, an interphase develops around the particles that exhibits a 30 times higher conductivity than the host phase. This is due to structural changes in the polymer invoked by the tendency for the lithium chemical potential between particles and matrix to equilibrate.  The room temperature Li conductivity is 0.2 mS/cm.

The most successful material developed in this project is a hybrid organic-inorganic electrolyte prepared using a two-step synthesis approach, in which a continuous silica network is formed first, and polymer is grafted onto the pore walls of this network structure second. In this material it is possible to simultaneously increase the elastic modulus and the ionic conductivity based on the variation of a single design parameter, thereby breaking the commonly observed inverse relationship between these two properties. The room temperature ionic conductivity for this hybrid electrolyte is 0.5 mS/cm.  The progress in improving solid-state electrolyte ionic conductivity throughout the project is illustrated in Fig. 1.

While the research in this project was focused on understanding the fundamental aspects underlying materials design for solid-state electrolytes, the work has significantly broader impact in that it directly benefits the technological sector of energy storage, which in turn is key to making clean and renewable energy sources economically and logistically viable. Hence, this project has contributed towards combatting pollution and global warming, and is has helped advance technologies ranging from consumer electronics to electric vehicles to grid energy storage.

This research served to train one graduate student, 12 undergraduate students, and two visiting researchers in the ways of conducting scientific research, reviewing the scientific literature critically, analytical and creative thinking, and the systematic pursuit of scientific discovery. It provided substance for outreach such as the ASM High School Teachers Camp, held annually at the University of Michigan.
